context: In <a5_0>1958<a5_0/>, he became a Boy Scout and fulfilled a requirement for the photography merit badge by making a nine-minute <b10_0><b14_0>8<b10_0/> mm<b14_0/> film entitled <a6_0>The Last Gunfight<a6_0/>. Years later, Spielberg recalled to a magazine interviewer, "My <a7_0>dad's still-camera was broken<a7_0/>, so I asked the scoutmaster if I could tell a story with my father's movie camera. He said yes, and I got an idea to do a <a4_0>Western<a4_0/>. I made it and got my merit badge. That was how it all started." At age <a8_0>thirteen<a8_0/>, while living in Phoenix, Spielberg won a prize for a <a1_0>40-minute<a1_0/> war film he titled Escape to Nowhere, using a cast composed of other high school friends. That motivated him to make 15 more amateur 8mm films.:548 In <b13_0>1963<b13_0/>, at age sixteen, Spielberg wrote and directed his first independent film, a <b12_0>140-minute<b12_0/> science fiction adventure called <a0_0><a9_0>Firelight<a9_0/><a0_0/>, which would later inspire Close Encounters. The film was made for <a2_0><b11_0>$500<b11_0/><a2_0/>, most of which came from <a3_0>his father<a3_0/>, and was shown in a local cinema for one evening, which earned back its cost.
